topic.title: Packet Generator and Checker

body.p: There is a single, line rate, TLP generator and checker located within the PPU block that is muxed with the outbound and inbound circular buffers.
This feature is supported in ChipLink.

fig.title: TLP Generator and Checker Block Diagram

body.p: TLP Generator (GEN) and Checker (CHK) is a diagnostic feature that allows the user to transfer and receive sustained and configurable TLP traffic. These diagnostic features are used for internal or external data path signal integrity and bandwidth testing.
For details and examples of this feature please refer to TLP Generator and Checker Command.

li.p: PPU implements a HW TLP generator capable of generating TLPs at line-rate with firmware control to configure the following:
Payload Length
Minimum gap between TLPs
Number of TLPs to transmit and address
The header value and sideband information (destination port, etc...) is configured by FW. The payload value starts with a seed and can have the following three variations:

ol.li:
Constant value
A constant value is generated from the seed

Incrementing value
Starting from the seed, the value increments every DWORD across all TLPs

Increment every TLP
Starting from the seed, the value increments every TLP

li.p: The following table shows a comparison of the three TLP generator modes
Note that the TLP checker must be enabled before TLP generator to ensure proper synchronization.
The PPU buffer is 320 entries. Each entry is 10 dwords plus 4 dwords for metadata (transparent data). The full buffer is split between the port and queues configured in the device. For example:
For an 8 port bifurcation mode with 3 queues per port, then the buffer supports 24 different queues.
The splitting of the buffer is programmable and done on entry boundaries.

note.p: The TLP packer in the PCIE processing unit (PPU) has a test generation mode in which it will ignore the MFA queue and directly read from the outbound buffers. In test generation mode, the PPU will be configurable to read TLPs from the outbound buffer and send them towards the switch core. The test generation mode is on a per-channel basis.

FW must halt the channel(s) that it wishes to use for test generation. FW will then fill the TLP buffers (P, NP, and C) for the channel with a number of TLPs to be sent in packet generation mode, including sideband signals for timestamp and for routing (if desired).

If FW wishes to loop over TLPs in the outbound buffers, FW sets the Loop Count and Loop Size registers to the number of loops and the number of TLPs to be looped over in each class of buffer. A value of 0 in the Loop Count register indicates indefinite looping.

FW can then place the channel into Packet Generation mode and restart the channel. The TLP packer will then fetch from the outbound buffers for that channel based on the packet generation registers; TLPs will be normally arbitrated based on timestamp. Setting the TLP Gap register will force the TLP packer to gap a set number of cycles between generated TLPs; however, the actual gap may be larger due to congestion in the switch core or in the rest of the fabric.

body.p: Because the pre-generated TLPs include destination information, the TLP generator is capable of generating TLPs destined for any switch port, including different switch ports.
Packet checking also supports the following:

li.p: PPU implements a HW TLP checker capable of checking TLPs at line-rate.
When enabled, the checker compares against a golden copy of the expected data and checks the TLP traffic for error, performance and latency. Note that the checker discards all received TLPs.
Error Detection
Upon detection of the first payload error, the checker reports the following information about the received TLP containing the error:
Entire 320-bit (10 Dwords) of the TLP (i.e., the specific TLP sample that did not match the golden copy).
Specific Dword(s) that did not match the golden copy
40-bit TLP data parity
TLP Metadata
The index number of the received TLP that contained the error. The index starts with 1 and increments with each received TLP
Performance

Checker can report performance by reporting the number of clocks cycles lapsed in receiving N number of packets. Note that the clock cycling count is triggered on the first received TLP write request after the timer is enabled
The checker continues counting TLPs even after detecting a TLP mismatch, allowing a separate count of total received TLPs and total received bad TLPs to be tracked.
Latency

The switch core metadata is continuously sampled on every new successful received TLP. Along with this metadata, a hardware timestamp value is sampled, allowing the firmware to compare timestamps and provide latency numbers
The TLP checker can be programmed to stop after receiving N number of TLPs or until the checker is forcefully stopped.

Similarly, the TLP unpacker may be programmed to operate in a Packet Checking mode. In packet checking mode, firmware halts the channel and fills the inbound buffers with packets expected to be received on the channel. Similar to packet generation, firmware sets the Loop Count and Loop Size registers for each buffer. Firmware then sets the channel into packet checking mode and restarts the channel.

Because of TLP re-ordering in the fabric, TLP checking is done on a per-type basis. Each channel/type starts out-of-sync; as TLPs are received, they are checked against the first TLP in the appropriate channel/type. Once a match is detected, the channel/type enters sync and the sync timer for that channel/type is started.

Any detected error/mismatch for a channel/type will stop the sync timer for that channel/type and cause an interrupt to firmware. Similarly, the timer(s) will be stopped if the number of TLPs specified in the Loop Count/Loop Size registers are received, or if firmware disables packet checking.
